review.title: Integrating active sensing into reactive synthesis with temporal logic constraints under partial observations
review.abstract: We introduce the notion of online reactive planning with sensing actions for systems with temporal logic constraints in partially observable and dynamic environments. With incomplete information on the dynamic environment, reactive controller synthesis amounts to solving a two-player game with partial observations, which has impractically computational complexity. To alleviate the high computational burden, online replanning via sensing actions avoids solving the strategy in the reactive system under partial observations. Instead, we only solve for a strategy that ensures a given temporal logic specification can be satisfied had the system have complete observations of its environment. Such a strategy is then transformed into one which makes control decisions based on the observed sequence of states (of the interacting system and its environment). When the system encounters a belief---a set including all possible hypotheses the system has for the current state---for which the observation-based strategy is undefined, a sequence of sensing actions are triggered, chosen by an active sensing strategy, to reduce the uncertainty in the system's belief. We show that by alternating between the observation-based strategy and the active sensing strategy, under a mild technical assumption of the set of sensors in the system, the given temporal logic specification can be satisfied with probability 1.

sections.heading: III. MAIN RESULTS
sections.text: In games with partial information, algorithms in [5] can be used to synthesize observation-based controllers that ensure that given temporal logic specifications are met securely or almost securely, i.e. with probability 1, whenever such controllers exist. In this article, we will consider only those cases where observation-based controllers do not exist and therefore require additional runtime information to meet given temporal logic specifications. We distinguish two phases in online planning: the progression phase and the sensing phase. As the names suggest, the system implements physical measures during the progression phase to satisfy the temporal logical limitations, and during the sensing phase, the system implements sensing measures to reduce uncertainty in its belief in the current game state. The transition from one phase to another is explained after we have presented the methods for synthesizing the strategies used in both phases.

sections.heading: IV. EXAMPLES
sections.text: Figure 2 consists of a mobile robot, a robot called "Wumpus." The robot is able to move in eight compass directions with actions "N," "S," "W," "NE," "NW," "SW" (horizontal, vertical and diagonal), one step at a time. The robot and the Wumpus do not move at the same time. The Wumpus can move in four compass directions with actions "N," "S," "W" and "W" within a limited area and emits stench to its surrounding cells. sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Our work shows that if additional information can be obtained through scanning actions, a sure winning strategy with complete information can be turned into a belief-based, randomized strategy, which is then combined with an active scanning strategy at runtime to ensure that a given temporal logic specification is satisfied with probability 1. The synthesis method avoids a subset construction to solve games with partial information. Meanwhile, the active scanning strategy results in a cost-effective way of sensor design: Although we need a sufficient number of scanning actions to avoid dead ends at runtime, the system minimizes the use of scanning actions by asking the most revealing queries depending on which specification is to be met and how much uncertainty the system has about the game state at runtime. In future work, we will look at more examples of practical robotic motion planning under partial observations.
